abstracts.cdata!:
While the outcome can not be considered
            fully satisfactory, the project's substantial
            contribution towards reorienting the sector and
            strengthening institutions at the central level can not be
            discounted. The most appropriate rating to assign is
            "moderately satisfactory". The project's
            achievements on the policy reform and institutional side
            have a high likelihood of being sustainable. The technical
            capacity in the area of public health, health information,
            licensing and accreditation, equipment planning and
            maintenance, pharmaceutical regulation and contracting for
            health services has substantially improved as a result of
            the project and will thus have lasting effects. However,
            many of the project's achievements will not be able to
            bear their full fruit unless public resources flowing into
            the sector will increase and the Government will make an
            increased commitment towards using these resources in a
            cost-effective manner. The Bank's overall performance
            is rated moderately satisfactory. Considering the complexity
            of the project and the fact that this was the first Bank
            project in the health sector in Georgia, the Borrower's
            overall performance is rated satisfactory. The key issue was
            the inadequate financing of the health sector, a problem
            well beyond the control of the implementing agencies.
            Briefly, these are some of the other lessons learned: 1)
            Align expectations with available resources. 2) Adapt
            project complexity to local conditions. 3) Payment reform
            alone is insufficient to bring about rationalization in the
            hospital sector, nor is it realistic to expect market forces
            alone to bring about the necessary hospital rationalization.
            4) Continuous dialogue with stakeholders is critical to
            assure support for reforms. 5)  Investment projects can
            support but seldom bring about policy reform. 6) Provide for
            adequate resources to fully implement activities initiated
            under projects. 7) Draw on international expertise to
            support complicated procurements. 8) Use long term
            fellowship training with caution and link it to an
            obligation of beneficiaries to return to their sponsoring
            institution for a minimum period of time. 9) Clearly outline
            expectations and roles of all involved in project
            implementation and establish a mechanism to assure regular
            communication and coordination across project components.
            10) An important lesson pertaining to technical assistance
            also is that terms of reference for consulting assignments
            should be developed in close collaboration with the
            beneficiary agency, but also be supported by relevant policy
            makers to assure that outputs will be adequately utilized.
            11) Support investments in public health and health
            promotion with an adequate monitoring system.
